subject: Learning
title: Writing Effective Flashcards
description: A 60-second lesson on Writing Effective Flashcards.

hook.text: A flashcard that says 'Tell me everything about photosynthesis' is useless. Good cards are atomic and specific.

buildup.text: The most effective flashcards test one fact per card, use clear prompts, and require active recallâ€”not recognition.

discovery.text: Piotr Wozniak's '20 rules' for flashcards include: learn before you memorize, use minimum information, and add context.

twist.text: Bad flashcards waste time and create illusions of knowledge. Card quality matters as much as review schedule.

climax.text: Use cloze deletions, image occlusion, and question-answer formatsâ€”each suits different material types.

punchline.text: A great flashcard asks one thing and has one answer. Keep it atomic.

quiz.question: What is the most important principle of effective flashcard design?
options: Each card should test one atomic fact with a clear prompt
Cards should contain as much information as possible
Only use text-based cards, never images
